subNodes.conversationText: root

When <FirstName> entered the circle, they began singing.

<FirstName> had heard Middle One sing little snatches of things before, but <he/she> had never heard Eldest Lady. Her voice was tuneful but harsh. Middle One's tenor was gentle and earnest. <He/She> recognized the rhyme they'd chanted at Knott's creation.
[Continue.]
More or less, less or more Death's a house without a door. Life's a squatter, rank and poor. More or less, less or more.
[Continue.]
Middle One added the next verse alone: Less or more, more or less, Desire's a bird without a nest. Where it builds it cannot rest Less or more, more or less.
[Continue.]

And Eldest Lady finished: More or less, less or more, Time's the straw it's looking for And the storm it sometimes flees And the branch it cannot seize Refugee from time's great war More or less, less or more.
[Continue.]

Then Eldest Lady turned to <FirstName>.

"A witch does and desires what others cannot. <He/She> sees the paths of kings and peasants and lets others walk them. No laws but <his/her> own govern <him/her>; gold is dross to <him/her>, and dross gold. <He/She> keeps <his/her> head in the world of flesh and <his/her> feet tangled in the Roots. Of all mortals, <he/she> is the closest to Namelessness: <he/she> traffics with kami, tutelars, ogres, and ghosts."
[Continue.]

"And yet <he/she> is alone. No house will host <him/her> long. No crowd will love <him/her>. No kin will own <him/her>. From the places people gather people will drive <him/her>. For though wisdom is always on <his/her> tongue and might in <his/her> hands, <his/her> shadow is misfortune -- And to be near <him/her> long means sometime coming into that shadow."
[Continue.]

"For this reason the witch binds <him/her>self to a coven. In it <he/she> has companionship, family, and government. Its bond surpasses the bonds of blood, and its three Laws surpass the laws of mere language. The Laws are not just words but truths, limiting and lifting <him/her> the way currents of air limit and lift the flights of birds."

"Come, <FirstName>, young witch. Middle One and I would have you join us." <FirstName> stepped forward.
[Continue.]

"Though you failed to bring us the blood of the third hunter, you killed two of the three and so showed us the way to the third. It's true that I had to bloody my hands myself to get those last guilty drops -- but I suppose yours were bloody enough already."
[Continue.]
<FirstName> had no choice but to accept this in silence.
Eldest Lady squinted at <FirstName>. "Now you must know about Malkin."

"For this reason the witch binds <him/her>self to a coven. In it <he/she> has companionship, family, and government. Its bond surpasses the bonds of blood, and its three Laws surpass the laws of mere language. The Laws are not just words but truths, limiting and lifting <him/her> the way currents of air limit and lift the flights of birds."

"Come, <FirstName>, young witch. Middle One and I would have you join us."
"I cannot, Eldest Lady. You know I cannot."
Eldest Lady took out a flask of blood. It was Eris's. "As for this woman's death -- you are not blameless. Would you let her blood go to waste?"
[Continue.]
<FirstName> was silent.
[Continue.]
"You have done well, <FirstName>! Better than expected. The coven has much to give you."
[Continue.]
[Continue.]
"I will join you," the young witch said.
"Good. Very good," said Eldest Lady. "You have done well."
[Continue.]
[Continue.]
"You deserve to know about Malkin. His secrets will be yours soon."
[Continue.]

"For this reason the witch binds <him/her>self to a coven. In it <he/she> has companionship, family, and government. Its bond surpasses the bonds of blood, and its three Laws surpass the laws of mere language. The Laws are not just words but truths, limiting and lifting <him/her> the way currents of air limit and lift the flights of birds."

"Come, <FirstName>, young witch." <FirstName> stepped forward, ready. "Middle One and I invite you to join us."
[Continue.]
The earth moved. The roots of the tree were shifting.
[Continue.]
Eldest Lady poured the blood over the ground. The earth shuddered, and new flowers of unearthly blue opened in the crimson grass.
[Continue.]

But for this I would not speak to you, Scheming nemesis, mistress of wickedness. But just this once you have my gratitude. My twisted being thirsted so; the coil I'd coiled so carefully around her heart Was tight until that arrow shot it through. If surfeit is my destiny, I will Have death for death, and soak all forwardness In perfect satisfaction of revenge.
[Continue.]
"Yes yes," said Eldest Lady, looking sideways at the young witch. "Enough chatter. Now we must perform the binding."
[Continue.]
A wind leapt up and shook the tree. There were words in the shaking boughs and  leaves, but the young witch could not make them out.
[Continue.]
The old witch listened. She looked satisfied. "Well, <FirstName>. It's time." She held out her hand.
[Continue.]

But even as Eldest Lady spoke the sky darkened. <FirstName> looked up. It was not a cloud passing over the sun. No: it was a cloud of insects. It moved slowly, a confused mass, no unity like you see in a flock of birds. Moths. <FirstName> heard the crashing of waves and saw red curtains billowing at the edge of the clearing.
[Continue.]
"The child, Middle One."
<FirstName> felt <his/her> stomach drop. Child?
Middle One did not respond to Eldest Lady's command. The witch only stared at the ground.
[Continue.]
"Middle One! The child!"
[Continue.]
Middle One whimpered and revealed what was beneath the cloth. It was the woodcutter's son, fast asleep.
[Continue.]

A wind leapt up and shook the tree. There were words in the shaking boughs and leaves: I am a husk where human feeling used To live -- but I am not an idol whose Curse or blessing you hags can solicit With your sacrifice. After all this time, Am I but appetite to you, I, whose wants Outstripped desire to win a crown of leaves?... I wanted vengeance, not this poor young thing. Return him to his father's cursed house.
[Continue.]

"He will not accept the boy. <FirstName> is enough," said Eldest Lady. Middle One wept with relief.

"Why are you glad, Middle One?" Eldest Lady asked, though her relief was evident too. "A part of him died with Nnenne. Without blood he won't get it back. We will not be what once we were."
A wind leapt up and shook the tree. There were words in the shaking boughs and  leaves, but the young witch could not make them out.
[Continue.]

"He will not accept the boy. <FirstName> is enough," said Eldest Lady. Middle One wept with relief.

"Why are you glad, Middle One?" Eldest Lady asked, though her relief was evident too. "A part of him died with Nnenne. Without blood he won't get it back. We will not be what once we were."
"What were you planning to do with that boy?" demanded <FirstName>.

"Do not trouble yourself with that," said Eldest Lady. She looked defeated -- a wizened, dimiished creature. Her many years had never been so apparent. "Only a few more words to say, and then we can go home."
"I'm confused," <FirstName> interrupted. "Who are you talking about?"

"Do not trouble yourself with that," said Eldest Lady. She looked defeated -- a wizened, dimiished creature. Her many years had never been so apparent. "Only a few more words to say, and then we can go home."
[Continue.]
"You must join us, <FirstName>," said Eldest Lady. "Come. Take my hand."
<FirstName> did.
"Good," she said, touching <FirstName> lightly on the cheek with the tips of her fingers, as if <he/she> was an infant she was admiring. "Good!" <FirstName> was surprised to see tears in her eyes.
[Continue.]

But even as Eldest Lady spoke the sky darkened. <FirstName> looked up. It was not a cloud passing over the sun. No: it was a cloud of insects. It moved slowly, a confused mass, no unity like you see in a flock of birds. Moths. <FirstName> heard the crashing of waves and saw red curtains billowing at the edge of the clearing.
<FirstName>  took out the woodcutter's axe instead.
"His axe!" cried Eldest Lady, stumbling back. "The woodcutter's axe!"
"No. I want none of this. I renounce the coven."
"Then you are a cowardly fool," said Eldest Lady.
[Continue.]
"Which is worse, sister? A cowardly fool, or a foolish coward?"
[Continue.]

"A cowardly fool. <His/Her> cowardice may pass but his folly sticks to <him/her>."

"Go, <FirstName>. I will not plead with you. I am a great witch, but I am not destiny, and it is destiny you turn your back on. If it doesn't urge you on, what could I possibly say?"
"You were going to sacrifice a boy."
"Yet I didn't. But what does that matter to one as high-minded as you, for whom intentions are as good as deeds, and the world a stage in a morality play? Begone. Begone."
"There's one last thing I need to do," <FirstName> said. <He/She> took out the woodcutter's axe.
"His axe!" cried Eldest Lady, stumbling back. "The woodcutter's axe!"
[Continue.]

"The axe has a haft, the haft has a head,
Half daft is my lady -- her lord is half dead."
[Continue.]
Eldest Lady clenched her fists. "The kami. They put you up to this. Don't you see, <FirstName>? They have enthralled you. Once you have done this work, they will destroy you as they destroyed him."
"But they didn't destroy him. I will."

"Stop!"

<FirstName> did. The command of Eldest Lady was not easy to resist. Even so, the old witch couldn't hold <him/her> long.
"I have more reason to trust them than I have to trust you."

"Stop!"

<FirstName> did. The command of Eldest Lady was not easy to resist. Even so, the old witch couldn't hold <him/her> long.
<He/She> ignored her and strode toward the tree that was Malkin.

"Stop!"

<FirstName> did. The command of Eldest Lady was not easy to resist. Even so, the old witch couldn't hold <him/her> long.
[Continue.]
"The blood of the hunters you slew cries out. They wlll not let you either."
[Continue.]

"What's this? My life was full of dreams of death --
Must death be stuffed with dreams of life? I loathe
The sun."
[Continue.]

"Let's hang this young witch, bleed <him/her> dry,
And then eat dust, await oblivion,
When all the world forgets us."
[Continue.]
"Come, Eris. This is your fight too."
[Continue.]

"Who wrests me from my rest? I am so thirsty
And confused... I thought I saw her as
I slept, but when I took her in my arms
I found the hated, living air...You...
I'll drink your blood, then seek her out again."
[Continue.]
[Continue.]

Eldest Lady had hoped the young witch would not challenge her, but she was not unprepared for it. She had resources beyond Malkin, beyond the coven, that only she knew and understood. Her power was a secret, silver spring that bubbled up around her when she willed. Seldom had she drawn as deeply as she drew from it now.
[Continue.]
"Nor will Eris, whose death you would rob of meaning."
[Continue.]

"Who wrests me from my rest? I am so thirsty
And confused... I thought I saw her as
I slept, but when I took her in my arms
I found but hated, living air...You...
I'll drink your blood, then seek her out again."
[Continue.]

Eldest Lady had hoped the young witch would not challenge her, but she was not unprepared for it. She had resources beyond Malkin, beyond the coven, that only she knew and understood. Her power was a secret, silver spring that bubbled up around her when she willed. Seldom had she drawn as deeply as she drew from it now.
[Continue.]
"Must we, sister? Must we?" quailed Middle One.
[Continue.]
"We must."
[Continue.]

Eldest Lady had hoped the young witch would not challenge her, but now that <he/she> had, she was not unprepared. She had resources beyond Malkin, beyond the coven, that only she knew and understood. Her power was a secret, silver spring that bubbled up around her when she willed. Seldom had she drawn as deeply as she drew from it now.
[Continue.]
"Must we, sister? Must we?" quailed Middle One.
[Continue.]
"We must."
There was nothing left to say. <FirstName> turned <his/her> back on Eldest Lady and Middle One.
Pharaoh croaked mournfully.
[Continue.]
Knott shambled over to Eldest Lady and stood by her side, seeming to watch the young witch.
[Continue.]
Eldest Lady cursed <him/her> as she left, but she lacked the will to injure <him/her>. The curse was carried away by the breeze.
[Continue.]
"You've never dealt honestly with me. Why would I join you?"
"I told you all you needed to know. Look: The truth has only confused you."
"You were going to sacrifice a boy."
"There's one last thing I need to do," <FirstName> said. <He/She> took out the woodcutter's axe.
There was nothing left to say. <FirstName> turned <his/her> back on Eldest Lady and Middle One.

But even as Eldest Lady spoke the sky darkened. <FirstName> looked up. It was not a cloud passing over the sun. No: it was a cloud of insects. It moved slowly, a confused mass, no unity like you see in a flock of birds. Moths. <FirstName> heard the crashing of waves and saw red curtains billowing at the edge of the clearing.
[Continue.]

"The Congress! The Congress!" Eldest Lady shrieked. "They must not interrupt us. Not now. This is our time; they will meddle with us no more. You are still unbound; step outside the circle and deal with them."
[End.]
"You're talking about Malkin, aren't you? Where is he?"

"Do not trouble yourself with that," said Eldest Lady. She looked defeated -- a wizened, dimiished creature. Her many years had never been so apparent. "Only a few more words to say, and then we can go home."
"So it was Malkin who wanted the blood. Why did you want to give it to him?"

"Do not trouble yourself with that," said Eldest Lady. She looked defeated -- a wizened, dimiished creature. Her many years had never been so apparent. "Only a few more words to say, and then we can go home."
<FirstName> asked no questions.

Then the sky darkened. <FirstName> looked up. It was not a cloud passing over the sun. No: it was a cloud of insects. It moved slowly, a confused mass, no unity like you see in a flock of birds. Moths.
[Continue.]
<FirstName> waited.
Middle One did not respond to Eldest Lady's command. The witch only stared at the ground.
"I am not sure. You have kept many things from me."
"Yes. Malkin. You wonder what his role is. You know he is bound to us, but you don't know what that means."
[Continue.]

"As I've told you, Malkin never left the coven. However, he is not wholly a witch and does not bring us to three. But with a proper third -- with Nnenne, or with you -- we are effectively greater than three."

"A traditional coven's power is nine times greater than that of a single witch. But with Malkin, our coven is greater by thirteen and a half."
"Then you break the Laws."
"I do not. The letter of the Laws is honored. As for the spirit of the Laws -- the Laws have no spirit. No one knows their framers, if framers they ever had."
"The Congress of Moths, perhaps? It would explain their interest in me."

She bristled at this idea. "The Congress? You have seen enough of them to know that isn't true. They legislate nothing. They delight in mocking human institutions, in arbitrary rules, in brutality. They pursue and fight us because doing so entertains them, not to punish injustice. Besides," she added, "there is no injustice here."
"What does the coven do with Malkin's power?"
"Then Malkin's power comes with no cost?"

"Of course there's a cost. A coven is a partnership. That is true even if one of the witches is no longer altogether a witch. Malkin's unhappiness must be our unhappiness; when he is infirm, we are infirm. And he is hostile to me. He blames me for what happened to him. It takes much to soothe his wayward will. You will see. You will see; but you will not regret your choice."
"You use Malkin against his will."

"His will is rotten. I dearly wish the kami had shown you what they showed me, the monster he would have become if he had never changed. Does he suffer, and does our bond chaff? Yes. But we keep him bent toward better ends than he would have pursued."
"There's something you're not telling me. Nnenne thought of Malkin as a parasite."
"I see," said <FirstName>. <He/She> knew all <he/she> was going to know.
"What does the coven do with Malkin's power?"
"What does that power do with us?"
"And this comes with no cost?"
"There's something you're not telling me. Nnenne thought of Malkin as a parasite."
"You use him against his will."
"I see," said <FirstName>. <He/She> knew all <he/she> was going to know.
"But why? What does the coven do with that power?"
"What does that power do with us?"
[Continue.]

"I will tell you something only very few know. There are many stories about me, about what I've done, about my age. Some say I was made when the world was made. Others, that I am only a few centuries old, and that older accounts of Eldest Lady refer to a different witch."
[Continue.]

"The truth is that I do not know. I do not know how old I am. I guess that I am very ancient, though certainly not as old as the world. Of my parentage, girlhood, and home I have dim recollections. I recall a stern old man who might have been my father. I can think back on a wooden hall in the style of the Caxi, the people who once lived in Dudow. Other things, too -- the greenest valleys, seen from afar...."
"You can't remember anything more? That is very sad."

"Sad? It is. But I tell you this not because I want your pity but so you can understand. All the oldest witches need their coven's power to keep living. But I am older still, perhaps oldest of all, and I need more. I don't pursue power for its own sake. I am no Malkin. My wants are small and human. I want only to live, to work my magic, to think of things and take pleasure in them..."
[Continue.]
"Too many years," the young witch mused. "The cup of memory overflows."

"Yes. Know, then, that I am old but not immortal. All the oldest witches need their coven's power to keep living. But I am older still, perhaps oldest of all, and I need more. I don't pursue power for its own sake. I am no Malkin. My wants are small and human. I want only to live, to work my magic, to think of things and take pleasure in them..."
[Continue.]
"Why are you telling me this? What does it have to do with the coven's power?"

"Do you not see? I am old but not immortal. All the oldest witches need their coven's power to keep living. But I am older still, perhaps oldest of all, and I need more. I don't pursue power for its own sake. I am no Malkin. My wants are small and human. I want only to live, to work my magic, to think of things and take pleasure in them..."
[Continue.]
"Oh, sister," said Middle One, always quick to tears.
[Continue.]
Eldest Lady tried to wave the other witch's tears away.
"You work against the Laws."
"I do not. The letter of the Laws is honored. As for the spirit of the Laws -- the Laws have no spirit. No one knows their framers, if framers they ever had."
"Is there no cost to the coven in having more than three?"

"Of course there's a cost. A coven is a partnership. That is true even if one of the witches is no longer altogether a witch. Malkin's unhappiness must be our unhappiness; when he is infirm, we are infirm. And he is hostile to me. He blames me for what happened to him. It takes much to soothe his wayward will. You will see. You will see; but you will not regret your choice."
"You use him against his will."
"There's something you're not telling me. Nnenne thought of Malkin as a parasite."
"I see," said <FirstName>. <He/She> knew all <he/she> was going to know.
"And this comes with no cost?"

"Of course there's a cost. A coven is a partnership. That is true even if one of the witches is no longer altogether a witch. Malkin's unhappiness must be our unhappiness; when he is infirm, we are infirm. And he is hostile to me. He blames me for what happened to him. It takes much to soothe his wayward will. You will see. You will see; but you will not regret your choice."
"There's something you're not telling me. Nnenne thought of Malkin as a parasite."
"As I explained to you before, she didn't know about him when she joined the coven. His presence was never agreeable to her. But in the end, Nnenne was Nnenne's enemy, not Malkin."
"What about the Laws? Don't you break them in keeping Malkin bound this way?"
"I do not. The letter of the Laws is honored. As for the spirit of the Laws -- the Laws have no spirit. No one knows their framers, if framers they ever had."
"What does the coven do with Malkin's power?"
"You use him against his will."
"I see," said <FirstName>. <He/She> knew all <he/she> was going to know.

"Nnenne had her own troubles," said Eldest Lady. "Troubles with men. Troubles that had nothing to do with Malkin. It is true that we are always aware of him -- just as we are aware of each other. But that is how all covens work. Nnenne's unhappiness was my own fault. When we bound her, she didn't know about Malkin."
"What about the Laws? Don't you break them in keeping Malkin bound this way?"
"What does the coven do with Malkin's power?"
"What does that power do with us?"
"You use him against his will."
"I see," said <FirstName>. <He/She> knew all <he/she> was going to know.
"You use him against his will."

"His will is rotten. I dearly wish the kami had shown you what they showed me, the monster he would have become if he had never changed. Does he suffer, and does our bond chaff? Yes. But we keep him bent toward better ends than he would have pursued."
"What does the coven do with Malkin's power?"
"What about the Laws? Don't you break them in keeping Malkin bound this way?"
"There's something you're not telling me. Nnenne thought of Malkin as a parasite."
"I see," said <FirstName>. <He/She> knew all <he/she> was going to know.
"I see," said <FirstName>. <He/She> knew all <he/she> was going to know.
The earth moved. The roots of the tree were shifting.
"I will join you."
Eldest Lady squinted at <FirstName>. "Now you must know about Malkin."
[Continue.]

"As I've told you, Malkin never left the coven. However, he is not wholly a witch and does not bring us to three. But with a proper third -- with Nnenne, or with you -- we are effectively greater than three."

"A traditional coven's power is nine times greater than that of a single witch. But with Malkin, our coven is greater by thirteen and a half."
